results.question: What method did the company use when Topic 606 in fiscal 2019 was adopted?
results.markdown_table_response: We use the modified retrospective method for accounting for the adoption of Topic 606 in fiscal 2019. We first estimate our revenue requirements for the current period using the same method that we used to estimate our revenue requirements for the preceding period. We then apply Topic 606 to our revenue requirements to determine the amounts of revenue recognized in the current period.
results.csv_string_response: The company used the modified retrospective method, which results in the recognition of the $0.5 million cumulative effect adjustment to the opening balance of retained earnings in fiscal 2019, net of tax. The company also recognized a $0.2 million cumulative effect adjustment, net of tax, to the opening balance of other noncurrent liabilities in fiscal 2019, a decrease to receivables of $7.6 million, an increase to inventories of $2.8 million, and an increase to prepaid expenses and other current assets of $6.9 million.
results.json_rows_response: The company used the modified retrospective method.

results.question: How much was the cumulative-effect adjustment to the opening balance of fiscal 2019 retained earnings?
results.markdown_table_response: We calculated the cumulative effect adjustment for the adoption of Topic 606 by first determining the amount of the difference between the opening balance of fiscal 2019 retained earnings and the opening balance of fiscal 2018 retained earnings. We then determined the cumulative effect adjustment by dividing the difference by the cumulative net decrease in the amount of retained earnings over the three fiscal years. We then added the cumulative effect adjustment to the opening balance of fiscal 2019 retained earnings.
results.csv_string_response: The cumulative effect adjustment to the opening balance of fiscal 2019 retained earnings was $1.5 million, as described in Note 2 of Consolidated Statements of Operations for the fiscal years ended May 26, 2019, May 27, 2018, and May 28, 2017.

results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.csv_string_response: The table below shows the average fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market at 31 December 2019 and 31 December 2018.
results.json_rows_response:
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined by using valuation techniques. These valuation techniques maximise the use of observable market data where it is available and rely as little as possible on entity specific estimates. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3.
Specific valuation techniques used to value financial instruments mainly include: • Dealer quotes for similar instruments; • The fair value of interest rate swaps is calculated as the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves; and • Other techniques, such as discounted cash flow analysis, are used to determine fair value for financial instruments.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response:
The basic earnings per share, or EPS, of the Company is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.
results.csv_string_response:
Basic EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock equivalents, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.

results.question: What are the two forms of revenue generated from contracts with customers?
results.markdown_table_response:
The Company will recognize revenue from contracts with customers in two different ways. The Company will report revenue in one of two ways as follows:
• A royalty-based method will be used to report revenue for the performance obligation, such as when the Company transfers services to a customer and the customer pays a royalty to the Company for the transfer of the services; and
• A sale-based method will be used to report revenue when the Company’s performance obligations are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer.
results.csv_string_response: The revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. When determining the transaction price of the contract, an adjustment is made if payment from a customer occurs either significantly before or significantly after performance, resulting in a significant financing component. None of the Company’s licenses and collaboration agreements contained a significant financing component at either December 31, 2019 or 2018.
results.json_rows_response: The two forms of revenue generated from contracts with customers are sales and royalty revenues. Sales revenues are recognized in the period of the related sales by Zyla and MainPointe. Royalty revenues are recognized in the period of the related sales by Zyla and MainPointe.
